q: Eric Schmidt drew fire for responding to a hypothetical question posed at a forum in Washington, D.C., about an implant that would let Google Inc. know what its users were thinking. He responded that Google Inc. 's policy is to get right up to the creepy line and not cross it, and an implant would cross the line. He also said that as users voluntarily share information online, it doesn't need users to type in search queries for the company to tailor the results. ''We do

Galeana, who runs dealerships in suburban Detroit, Florida and South Carolina, said he is impressed with the turnaround that Sergio Marchionne engineered. ''I think this guy is a visionary,'' he said. He talks about what he needs to do and he goes out and gets it done. Mr Bush as presiding over a national security process marked by incoherent decision-making and policy drift. Mr Donald Rumsfeld suggests Mr Bush was at fault for not doing more to resolve disagreements among senior advisers. The president did not always receive, and may not have insisted on, a timely consideration of his options before he made a decision, nor did he always receive effective implementation of the decisions he made, Mr Donald Rumsfeld wrote. In the account, that the Los Angeles Times describes as one about ''shifting blame and settling scores'', Donald Rumsfeld writes that President Bush never asked him whether invading Iraq was the right course to take. While President Bush and I had many discussions about the war preparations, I do not recall his ever asking me if I thought going to war with Iraq was the right decision, he writes. The President Bush was the one charged with the tough choice to commit US forces. ''I did not speculate on the thought process that brought him to his ultimate, necessarily lonely
